==References== *Campbell, Gordon, The Grove Encyclopedia of Decorative Arts, Volume 2'', "Door", p. 318, Oxford University Press US, 2006, {{ISBN|0-19-518948-5}}, {{ISBN|978-0-19-518948-3}} [https://books.google.com/books?id=jGsVHV098K0C&pg=RA1-PA318&dq=Plock+Cathedral+doors&ei=l6c8S7L9MJeCygSHrrymAQ&cd=2#v=onepage&q=Plock%20Cathedral%20doors&f=false online] *Calkins, Robert G.; ''Monuments of Medieval Art'', Dutton, 1979, {{ISBN|0-525-47561-3}} *Nesbitt, Alexander, ''On the Bronze Doors in the Cathedral of Gnesen'', in ''The Archaeological Journal'', London, Volume 9, 1852? [https://books.google.com/books?id=h-U9AAAAcAAJ&pg=PA348&dq=Gnesen+Doors&lr=&as_brr=3&ei=4Ms6S_ykCJ_qzASFw73nCQ&cd=2#v=onepage&q=Gnesen%20Doors&f=false online] *Swarzenski, Hanns. ''Monuments of Romanesque Art; The Art of Church Treasures in North-Western Europe'', [[Faber and Faber]], 1974, {{ISBN|0-571-10588-2}} *Zofia Kurnatowska, U źródeł Polski, p. 148, Warszawa-Wrocław 2002 (in Polish)
==Further reading== * The standard work is (in Polish) ''Drzwi Gnieźnieńskie'', 3 volumes, ed. M. Walicki, Wrocław, 1956 * [[Adolph Goldschmidt|Goldschmidt, Adolph]], ''Die Bronzetüren von Nowgorod und Gnesen'', Marburg 1932, (Die frühmittelalterlichen Bronzetüren. 2) * Pavol Černý: ''Das Leben des hl. Adalbert von Prag auf der Bronzetür von Gnesen''. In: Tausend Jahre Benediktiner in den Klöstern Břevnov, Braunau und Rohr. EOS Verlag Erzabtei St. Ottilien 1993, ISSN 0303-4224.
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20060603211854/http://www.gniezno.home.pl/index.php?p_portal_pokaz=strony&p_strony_idname=1071132853 Images of the Gniezno Door on official website of Gniezno] {{pl icon}} Reasonable photos of each panel *[http://webcache.googleusercontent.com/search?q=cache:ZFM84APQFsEJ:www.dietmaralbrecht.de/Fokus_Ostsee/Ars_Baltica/ars_baltica.html+bronzetueren+gnesen&hl=en&gl=us&ct=clnk&cd=6 Bronze Doors]{{dead link|date=January 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} {{de icon}} {{commons category|Gniezno Door}}

[[Bernie Wrightson]] |TPB = |ISBN = |TPB# = |ISBN# = |subcat = X-Men |altcat = |sort = Heroes for Hope }} '''''Heroes for Hope: Starring the X-Men''''' is a 1985 [[Marvel Comics|Marvel]] [[comic book]] designed to raise awareness about hunger in Africa. Proceeds from the comic went to the [[American Friends Service Committee]], to assist in their work on behalf of [[Africa]]n [[famine]] relief and recovery. Published in the form of a "[[comic jam]]," or [[exquisite corpse]], the book featured an [[all-star]] lineup of comics creators as well as a few notable authors from outside the comic book industry, such as [[Stephen King]], [[George R. R. Martin]], and [[Edward Bryant]]. It also saw a rare [[Alan Moore]] Marvel Comics credit outside his early [[Marvel UK]] work. ''Heroes for Hope'' featured some memorable artist/writer and penciler/inker pairings, including [[Stan Lee]] and [[John Buscema]]; [[Stephen King]] and [[Bernie Wrightson]]; Moore and [[Richard Corben]]; [[Harlan Ellison]], [[Frank Miller (comics)|Frank Miller]], and [[Bill Sienkiewicz]]; [[Mike Baron]] and [[Steve Rude]], [[Howard Chaykin]] inked by [[Walt Simonson]]; and [[John Byrne (comics)|John Byrne]] and [[Terry Austin (comics)|Terry Austin]] reuniting on the X-Men. == Publication history == ''Heroes for Hope'' came about in response to the devastating [[1983–85 famine in Ethiopia]].{{cite book|last = DeFalco|first = Tom|authorlink = Tom DeFalco|last2= Gilbert|first2= Laura, ed.|chapter= 1980s|title = Marvel Chronicle A Year by Year History|publisher = [[Dorling Kindersley]]|year = 2008|page = 223|isbn =978-0756641238|quote= Horrified by the plight of starving children in Africa, writer/artist Jim Starlin and illustrator Bernie Wrightson convinced Marvel to publish ''Heroes For Hope''. It was a 'jam' book...and all of Marvel's profits were donated to famine relief in Africa.}} The concept was in the spirit of contemporaneous [[benefit concert|musical fund-raisers]] like [[Band Aid (band)|Band Aid]]'s "[[Do They Know It's Christmas?]]", [[USA for Africa]]'s "[[We Are the World]]", and the [[Live Aid]] concerts. Then-Marvel Comics editor-in-chief [[Jim Shooter]] described the genesis of the project this way: {{quote|One night, a few months ago, artist [[Jim Starlin]] called me at home to propose an idea that his friend and fellow artist [[Berni Wrightson]] had suggested to him — that Marvel Comics publish a special issue of ''The X-Men'', a benefit book for famine relief in Africa. Jim and Berni wanted to do the book as a "jam," with as many artists and writers contributing, which would enable us to bring a small army of outstanding talents together on the project, making it a real event. I thought it was a great idea. The next morning I pitched it to Publisher [[Mike Hobson]] and President [[Jim Galton]]. . . . Jim and Berni recruited the artists. [[Chris Claremont]] . . . quickly volunteered to recruit writers, and to help . . . coordinate the entire project.Shooter, Jim. Afterword, ''Heroes for Hope: Starring the X-Men'' (Marvel Comics, 1985).}} In addition to the contributors donating their work for the project, so did logo designer [[Janet Jackson (comics)|Janet Jackson]] and Marvel's production staff; while [[Curtis Circulation Company]] and all the [[direct market]] distributors and [[comics specialty shop]]s donated their profits. == Plot == The comic book opens with [[Rachel Summers]] poking her head out of the [[X-Mansion]] to grab the mail, only to be confronted with a horrible sight. The X-Men rush to the entrance to see that the mansion has somehow been transported to the middle of a barren desert. After retrieving the comatose mail carrier, [[Wolverine (character)|Wolverine]] senses that all is not right, and claws him in the face. But it turns out that it was all an illusion. The X-Men go back to business as usual after this fiasco, but then things begin to go wrong. One by one, a series of psychic assaults is launched on each member of the team, as they are subjected to their greatest subconscious fears. First [[Colossus (comics)|Colossus]] (with art by Byrne and Austin) is mocked by steely apparitions of his teammates. This is more than he can bear, and he curls up in a [[fetal position]]. [[Kitty Pryde]], as told by King, Wrightson, and inker [[Jeffrey Catherine Jones|Jeff Jones]], goes to grab something from the refrigerator only to be surprised by an evil Death-type being in a cloak. He exposes Kitty's great fear of going hungry. As told by [[Bill Mantlo]], [[Charles Vess]], and [[Jon J Muth]], [[Nightcrawler (comics)|Nightcrawler]] finds Kitty turned into a wizened old hag, which leads to his own experience, focusing on [[Christian]] imagery and moral dilemmas. Kurt is offered the chance to sacrifice himself so that one other person might breath the air and eat the food he would. He declines, and thinks himself a coward. Thanks to Moore and [[Richard Corben]], the next to fall prey to the spiritual onslaught is [[Magneto (comics)|Magneto]], who is offered a glimpse of a world where his dream of mutant supremacy has been realized — and that it's not all it's cracked up to be. Rachel is swept back to her past, where she's confronted by a horde of mutant-hunting [[doppelgänger]] [[Hounds (comics)|Hounds]], reminding her of her part in that dystopian future. Wolverine, by Ellison, Miller, and inker Sienkiewicz, must confront the tension between his human and animal sides. Claremont, [[Brian Bolland]], and [[P. Craig Russell]] depict [[Ororo|Storm]] confronted by a carnival ringmaster, who traps her in a [[house of mirrors]]. She is shown various images of her possible self, each one more distorted than the last. Ororo gets drawn into the crazy carnival games, and in the first concrete expression of the story's theme, she realizes that it is wrong to waste food. Having defeated the psychic attacker by feeding illusory cream pies to illusory people, Storm returns to her teammates for discussion of what has transpired. Courtesy of Rachel's powers, the X-Men track the psychic presence that's been harassing them to the continent of Africa. They fly the [[Blackbird (comics)|Blackbird]] to the source, where they are met with horrible scenes of deprivation. Before long, a fleet of [[C-130 Hercules]] transport aircraft arrive, full of supplies, which the X-Men help distribute. That night, [[Rogue (comics)|Rogue]] becomes so frustrated that she has not had her turn of psychic punishment yet that she decides to hunt down the entity herself. She sneaks around the campsite stealing her teammates' powers. Using the psychic powers of Rachel Summers, the Rogue hybrid traces the presence of the X-Men's harasser to a desert hideaway. Upon entering the crypt, Rogue is attacked by the avatar of the psychic being. Things are not going well for Rogue when Storm appears to give aid. The "entity" is revealed to be a primeval god-force that feeds on human despair. One by one, the X-Men awake from their Rogue-induced comas and join in the battle. The X-Men finally defeat the entity and return to their campsite, where they resume the enormous task of feeding the starving refugees. They realize their battle with the entity was a metaphor for the fight against famine, and indeed any human struggle. Kitty expresses fear that the entity survived the battle and is ready to strike again, but Wolverine comforts her with words of hope. == Contributors == ''Heroes for Hope'' featured a story by [[Chris Claremont]], [[Ann Nocenti]], [[Bernie Wrightson]], [[Jim Starlin]], and [[Jim Shooter]]. The editors were Nocenti and Claremont; the assistant editors were [[Pat Blevins]] and [[Terry Kavanagh]]. Front cover by [[Arthur Adams (comics)|Arthur Adams]]; back cover by Starlin. Logo design by [[Janet Jackson (comics)|Janet Jackson]]. {| class="wikitable" |- bgcolor="#CCCCCC" ! Page !! Writer !! Penciler !! Inker !! Letterer !! |45-48 || [[Archie Goodwin (comics)|Archie Goodwin]] || [[Howard Chaykin]] || [[Walt Simonson]] || [[Ken Bruzenak]] || [[Leslie Zahler]] |- |} == Awards == ''Heroes for Hope'' producers Jim Starlin and Bernie Wrightson were co-recipients of the 1986 [[List of Eisner Award winners#Bob Clampett Humanitarian Award|Bob Clampett Humanitarian Award]] for their work on the book.{{cite web |url= {{Use mdy dates|date=May 2018}} {{short description|fabric designs by Judith Weinshall Liberman}} {{Infobox Artwork | image=The_Yellow_Star.jpg | caption=''Yellow Star'' by Judith Weinshall Liberman (1994) / Scenes of the Holocaust / 51"x51" | title=Holocaust Wall Hangings | artist= Judith Weinshall Liberman | year= created 1988–2002 | medium= [[Paint]], [[appliqué]], [[embroidery]], [[stencil]]ing, [[beadwork]], [[woodblock printing|block printing]], [[transfer paper|image transfer]] | museum=[[Temple Tifereth-Israel]], [[Florida Holocaust Museum]], [[Yad Vashem|Yad Vashem Museum]] }}
The '''''Holocaust Wall Hangings''''' by [[Judith Weinshall Liberman]] are a series of sixty loose-hanging fabric banners of varying sizes created between 1988 and 2002.<ref name="theclevelandjewishnews"/><ref name="holocaustwallhangings5"/> They illustrate the plight of the [[Jews|Jewish people]] and other minorities during the [[Holocaust]] of [[World War II]].<ref name="JudithWeinshallLiberman1"/><ref name="holocaustwallhangings4">{{cite web|url=https://www.law.umich.edu/quadrangle/spring2013/Documents/spring2013_classnotes_liberman.pdf |first=Amy Wimmer |last=Schwarb |title=Judith Liberman, LLM ’56: Remembering the Holocaust through Art |publisher=[[University of Michigan]] | accessdate=14 April 2018}}</ref>
==Background== Judith Weinshall Liberman was born in 1929 and grew up in [[Haifa]], [[Mandatory Palestine]] (present-day [[Israel]]) during the time of the Holocaust.<ref name="nbcnews">{{cite web|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/id/16156588/ns/travel-destination_travel/t/jewish-museum-features-holocaust-horror/ | title= Jewish museum features Holocaust horror | publisher=NBC News | accessdate=19 April 2018}}</ref> In 1947, she moved to America to attend college and received four American university degrees including a J.D. degree from the [[University of Chicago Law School]] and an LL.M. degree from the [[University of Michigan Law School]]. In 1956, she turned her attention to the arts<ref name="JudithWeinshallLiberman1">{{cite web|url=https://www.law.uchicago.edu/news/judith-weinshall-liberman-54-life-art | title=Judith Weinshall Liberman, '54: A Life into Art |publisher=[[University of Chicago Law School]] | accessdate=14 April 2018}}</ref> and began studying drawing, painting, sculpture, and other art mediums at the Art Institute of Boston (then called the School of Practical Art),<ref name="Libermanwebsite"/> the School of the Museum of Fine Arts,<ref name="Libermanwebsite">{{cite web|url=http://www.jliberman.com/curriculum.html#art|title= Judith Weinshall Liberman, Curriculum Vitae |website=''jliberman.com''| accessdate=23 April 2018}}</ref><ref name="schoolofmuseumoffinearts">{{cite web|url=https://smfa.tufts.edu/ | title=School of the Museum of Fine Arts | publisher=[[Tufts University]] | accessdate= May 10, 2018}}</ref> the DeCordova Museum School,<ref name="Libermanwebsite"/> the [[Boston University College of Fine Arts]]<ref name="Libermanwebsite"/> and the [[Massachusetts College of Art and Design]].<ref name="Libermanwebsite"/>
In 1988, after spending a year painting more than two dozen works about the Holocaust on stretched canvas<ref name="holocaustwallhangings5"/>{{rp|2}} Weinshall Liberman began using loose-hanging fabric as the background for her art.<ref name="holocaustwallhangings5"/> In her 2002 book, ''Holocaust Wall Hangings'',<ref name="holocaustwallhangings5">{{cite Book|url=https://archive.org/details/holocaustwallhan00libe |first = Judith | last=Weinshall Liberman |date=2002 | title= Holocaust Wall Hangings | isbn=0-9719027-0-4| publisher=Schoen Books |location=South Deerfield, MA |via=archive.org| accessdate=17 April 2018}}</ref> Weinshall Liberman reveals that the decision to place Holocaust-themed imagery on loose-hanging fabric was inspired by her childhood memories of [[propaganda in Nazi Germany|propaganda]] banners and flags of the [[Nazi Germany|Third Reich]]<ref name="nazipropaganda">{{cite web|url=https://www.ushmm.org/wlc/en/article.php?ModuleId=10005202 | title= Nazi Propaganda | website=Holocaust Encyclopedia | accessdate=17 April 2018}}</ref><ref name="holocaustwallhangings5"/>{{rp|1}} that were typically hung on podiums, balconies, and walls at [[National Socialist German Workers' Party]] (NSDAP) rallies and ceremonies.<ref name="podiumanddecorativebannersofthethriedreich">{{cite web|url=https://www.crwflags.com/fotw/flags/de%7Dnspod.html | title=CRW Flags, Podiums and Decorative Banners of the Third Reich | website= | accessdate=17 April 2018}}</ref> Because these banners and their [[Nazi symbolism|insignia]] promoted [[Nazism|Nazi ideology]] and [[Genocides in history|genocide]], Weinshall Liberman found it fitting to use similar hanging fabrics in her art tribute to those who suffered during the Holocaust.<ref>{{cite book |last=Weinshall Liberman |first=Judith |date=2007 |title=My Life into Art – An Autobiography | page=266 | isbn=978-0-9719027-1-8}}</ref>
[[File:Hands Up from the Holocaust Wall Hangings Collection.jpg|upright=2.0 |left|thumbnail|alt=Hands Up by Judith Weinshal Liberman, 1989, 46" x 97"|''Hands Up'' by Judith Weinshall Liberman (1989) / Scenes of the Holocaust / 46"x97"]]
The Holocaust Wall Hangings are grouped into three categories: ''Scenes of the Holocaust,'' which focus on people portrayed as totally isolated or depicted as part of a depersonalized mass;<ref name="holocaustwallhangings5"/> ''Maps of the Holocaust'' <ref name="annefrankhonored">{{cite web|url=https://www.clevelandjewishnews.com/news/culture/exhibitions/anne-frank-honored-in-unique-program-at-the-temple/article_90d1f222-e709-11e6-97ec-9f379b50d93c.html | first = Carlo | last= Wolff | title=Anne Frank honored in unique program at the temple | publisher=[[Cleveland Jewish News]] | accessdate=17 April 2018}}</ref> which document the Holocaust with places, numbers.<ref name="clevelandjewishnews8">{{cite web|url=https://www.clevelandjewishnews.com/archives/powerful-works-on-fabric-a-tribute-to-holocaust/article_d2d3ede2-ccea-50a0-87a6-7a10c3ba1bcf.html | first=Fran | last=Heller | title=Powerful works on fabric a tribute to the Holocaust | publisher= [[Cleveland Jewish News]] | accessdate=17 April 2018}}</ref> and other symbols of destruction,<ref name="holocaustwallhangings5"/>{{rp|1}} and a third group, the ''Epilogue'' wall hangings, which mostly explore God's relationship to the Holocaust.<ref>{{cite book |last=Weinshall Liberman |first=Judith |date=2002 |title=Holocaust Wall Hangings | publisher=Schoen Book | page=2 | isbn=0-9719027-0-4}}</ref>
==Materials== To convey her feelings about the Holocaust, Weinshall Liberman chose fabrics ranging in height from {{convert|18|to|97|in|cm}} and in length from {{convert|21|to|172|in|cm}}.<ref name="holocaustwallhangings5"/>{{rp|61–78}} She used a color palette of mostly red, gray and black – red: blood and fire; gray: suffering and despair; black: death<ref name="holocaustwallhangings5"/>{{rp|1}} – and besides the primary use of painting and [[woodblock printing|block printing]], Weinshall Liberman utilized various combinations of [[stenciling]], [[sewing]], [[appliqué]], [[embroidery]], [[beading]], and [[transfer paper|image transfer]].<ref name="holocaustwallhangings5"/>{{rp|80}}
[[File:Triangles by Judith Weinshall Liberman.jpg|upright=2.0|thumb|alt=Triangles by Judith Weinshall Liberman, 1998, 33"x114" | ''Triangles'' by Judith Weinshall Liberman (1998) / Scenes of the Holocaust / 33"x114"]]
==Exhibitions== The ''Holocaust Wall Hangings'' have been displayed in exhibitions in the United States, Israel, and Hungary and have been featured in numerous museums and other public institutions including [[Yad Vashem]]<ref name="yadvashemmuseum">{{cite web|url=http://www.yadvashem.org/ | title=Home page |website=Yad Vashem | accessdate=13 April 2018}}</ref> in [[Jerusalem]], Israel; the Mishkan Le’Omanut Museum<ref name="israelmuseum">{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/10/13/t-magazine/israel-art-museum-ein-harod.html | title=The Mishkan Le’Omanut Museum | website=The New York Times | accessdate=20 April 2018}}</ref> in [[Ein Harod]], Israel; the [[Florida Holocaust Museum]] in [[St. Petersburg, Florida]]; the Temple Museum of Jewish Art, Religion and Culture <ref name="jewishartrelgionandculturemuseum">{{cite web|url=http://www.ttti.org/museums/the-temple-museum-of-jewish-art-religion-and-culture | title= The Temple Museum of Jewish Religion, Art and Culture | publisher=The Temple-Tifereth Israel | accessdate=19 April 2018}}</ref> of the [[Temple Tifereth-Israel]] in Beachwood, Ohio; the [[Maltz Museum of Jewish Heritage]]<ref name="templetiferethmaltzmuseum">{{cite web|url=http://www.maltzmuseum.org/about/the-temple-tifereth-israel-gallery/ | title=The Temple-Tifereth Israel Gallery |publisher= Maltz Museum of Jewish Heritage | accessdate=17 April 2018}}</ref> in Beachwood, Ohio; the [[DeCordova Museum and Sculpture Park|DeCordova Museum]] in Lincoln, Massachusetts; and at the [[Long Island Museum of American Art, History, and Carriages]] in [[Long Island, New York]]. In 2009, the wall hangings were featured at the [[Rumbach Street Synagogue]] in [[Budapest]], [[Hungary]] in the exhibit ''Anne Frank in the Artists' Eyes'',<ref name="annefrankintheartistseyes">{{cite web|url=http://www.members.aon.at/austrianart/anne_frank.htm | title= Rumbach Street Synagogue – Anne Frank in the Artists' Eyes | accessdate=17 April 2018}}</ref> bringing recognition to the 80th birthday of [[Anne Frank]].
==Critical responses== Judith Weinshall Liberman's ''Holocaust Wall Hangings'' have been recognized by publications and institutions such as ''[[The New York Times]]'',<ref name="NYTimes-28Feb99">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1999/02/28/nyregion/art-reviews-unorthodox-uses-of-paper-and-other-materials.html |date=February 28, 1999 |at=Sec. N.Y. / Region |first=Helen A. | last=Harrison | title=Art Reviews; Unorthodox Uses of Paper and Other Materials | work=[[The New York Times]] | accessdate=19 April 2018}}</ref> ''[[NBC News]]'',<ref name="nbcnews3">{{cite news|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/id/16156588/ns/travel-destination_travel/t/jewish-museum-features-holocaust-horror/ | title= Jewish museum features Holocaust Horror | publisher=[[NBC News]] |location=Beachwood, Ohio |agency=[[Associated Press]] | date=December 12, 2006 | accessdate=19 April 2018}}</ref> the Holocaust Teacher Resource Center,<ref name="holocaustteacherresourcecenter">{{cite web|url=http://www.holocaust-trc.org/holocaust-wall-hangings/ | work=Holocaust Teacher Resource Center site | title=Holocaust Wall Hangings |accessdate=19 April 2018}}</ref> the ''[[Tampa Bay Times]]''<ref name="tampabaytimes2">{{cite web|url=http://www.tampabay.com/features/visualarts/review-artist-of-great-mind-and-talent-has-a-show-one-flight-up-at-florida/1253301 | first=Lennie | last=Bennett | title=Review: Artist of Great Mind and Talent has a Show One Flight Up at Florida Holocaust Museum | work=Tampa Bay Times | accessdate=19 April 2018}}</ref> and the ''[[Cleveland Jewish News]]''.<ref name="theclevelandjewishnews">{{cite web|url=https://www.clevelandjewishnews.com/archives/powerful-works-on-fabric-a-tribute-to-holocaust/article_d2d3ede2-ccea-50a0-87a6-7a10c3ba1bcf.html | first=Fran | last=Heller | title=Powerful Works on Fabric a Tribute to Holocaust | publisher=Cleveland Jewish News | accessdate=19 April 2018}}</ref> Helen A. Harrison of the ''New York Times'' states that within the Holocaust Wall Hangings, "Abstraction and repetition are applied to the symbolism of repression, removing it from the realm of personal suffering and elevating it to the level of universal tragedy."<ref name="NYTimes-28Feb99"/> Ori Soltes, art and theology teacher at [[Georgetown University]] and former director of the B’nai B’rith Klutznick National Jewish Museum in Washington, D.C., believes that the soft materials Weinshall Liberman uses in her work "provide an important contrast to the Holocaust tragedy."<ref name="nbcnews3"/> Soltes says, "Using that kind of material for something which is so harsh and hard-edged to my mind is sort of an interesting conceptual leap."<ref name="nbcnews3"/> In her article "Powerful Works on Fabric a Tribute to Holocaust,"<ref name="clevelandjewishnews12">{{cite web|url=https://www.clevelandjewishnews.com/archives/powerful-works-on-fabric-a-tribute-to-holocaust/article_d2d3ede2-ccea-50a0-87a6-7a10c3ba1bcf.html | first=Fran | last=Heller | title=Powerful works on fabric a tribute to Holocaust | publisher= [[Cleveland Jewish News]] | accessdate=17 April 2018}}</ref> critic Fran Heller of the ''Cleveland Jewish News'' notes that "Liberman's color palette of red, gray and black symbolizes blood and fire, suffering, despair and death (and) it is both forceful and aesthetically moving."<ref name="theclevelandjewishnews"/>
==Archives== The Judith Weinshall Liberman Papers, 1960–2003,<ref name="archivesofamericanartsmithsonian">{{cite web|url=https://www.aaa.si.edu/collections/judith-weinshall-liberman-papers-13348| title= Judith Weinshall-Liberman Papers - 13348 |publisher=The Smithsonian Institute, Archives of American Art | accessdate=May 10, 2018}}</ref> a collection of photographs, slides, videos and manuscripts of panel discussions and exhibition installations<ref name="weinshalllibermafamilypapers">{{cite web|url=https://beta.worldcat.org/archivegrid/collection/data/871036203 |title= ArchiveGrid Weinshall-Liberman Family Papers, 1915–1995 | website=''worldcat.org'' | accessdate=13 April 2018}}</ref> relating to the ''Holocaust Wall Hangings'', has been catalogued by the [[Smithsonian Institution]]'s [[Archives of American Art]]. Weinshall Liberman's book ''Holocaust Wall Hangings''<ref name="holocaustwallhangings5"/> (2002), a companion piece to the wall hanging collection, has been digitally archived in the Fine Arts Department at the [[Boston Public Library]].<ref name=”holocaustwallhanings11”>{{cite web|url=https://archive.org/details/holocaustwallhan00libe| title=Holocaust Wall Hangings | publisher=Boston Public Library | accessdate=23 April 2018|via=Archive.org}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.jliberman.com/gallery%20holocaust%20wh/holocaust%20wh.html ''Holocaust Wall Hangings'' Online Gallery] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xMw5A0brvRU "Anne Frank series of the Holocaust Wall Hangings, Artist Judith Liberman comments"] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pFUaVgK4VFI "The Holocaust Wall Hangings – an exhibition of textile artwork at the Decordova Museum"]

{{Use mdy dates|date=May 2018}} {{Infobox museum | name = House-Museum of Jafar Jabbarly | native_name = {{lang-az|Cəfər Cabbarlının ev-muzeyi}} | native_name_lang = [[Azerbaijani language|Azerbaijani]] | logo = | logo_upright = | logo_alt = | logo_caption = | image = | image_upright = | alt = | caption = | map_type = Azerbaijan | map_relief = | map_size = | map_caption = Location within Azerbaijan | coordinates = {{coord|40.367954|N|49.822053|E}} | former_name = | established = {{start date and age|1979}} | dissolved = | location = I. Gutgashinli Street, 44, [[Baku]], Azerbaijan | type = | accreditation = | key_holdings = | collections = | collection_size = 10.000+ | visitors = | founder = | executive_director = | leader_type = | leader = | director = Gulara Jabbarly
Gamar Seyfaddingizi | president = | ceo = | chairperson = | curator = | architect = | historian = | owner = | publictransit = {{Bahnlinie|M|2||black|green|black}} [[Elmlər Akademiyası (Baku Metro)|Elmlar Akademiyasi metro station]] | car_park = | parking = | network = | website = {{url|cabbarli.ev-muzeyi.az}} | embedded = }} The '''house-museum of Jafar Jabbarly''' ({{lang-az|'''Cəfər Cabbarlının ev muzeyi'''}}) is a memorial museum dedicated to the [[Azerbaijani people|Azerbaijani]] playwright, poet, director and screenwriter, [[Jafar Jabbarly]]. ==History== [[File:Jafar_Jabbarly_2.jpg|154px|thumb|left|
[[Jafar Jabbarly]]
]] The museum is located in a house, where Jafar Jabbarly lived and created, in I. Gutgashinli Street, [[Baku]]. It first began operating in 1979 in connection with the 80th anniversary of the writer.{{cite web|title= 35 illik ömrün 30 yaşlı muzeyi|url= http://www.anl.az/down/meqale/medeniyyet/medeniyyet_mart2009/71371.htm|publisher= anl.az|language= az|accessdate=March 6, 2018}} During these period, the museum had only 57 exhibits.{{cite web|title= Cəfər Cabbarlinin Ev Muzeyi 35 il|url= http://cabbarli.ev-muzeyi.az/index.php?newsid=422|publisher= cabbarli.ev-muzeyi.az|language= az|accessdate=March 6, 2018}} The official inauguration was held in March 22, 1982. The [[President of the Republic of Azerbaijan]], [[Heydar Aliyev]] attended the opening ceremony. ==Exhibition and activity== The total area of the museum is 200 m2 and it consists of 7 rooms. Currently, over 10,000 exhibits are preserved in the fund of the museum. Documents and photographs reflecting life and creativity of the writer, his rare manuscripts, personal belongings of the writer and his family, used by the writer when he was alive, stage models designed for separate dramatic works, posters and programs from plays, paintings are exhibited to the audience. Also, gifts from prominent personalities to the dramatist, scientific works that investigate the literary heritage of Jabbarly, press examples are between collection of the museum.{{cite web|title= Cəfər Cabbarlının ev muzeyi|url= http://cabbarli.ev-muzeyi.az/#story|publisher= cabbarli.ev-muzeyi.az|language= az|accessdate=March 6, 2018}} The museum compiles and publishes books that consist of works of Jabbarly and his creativity. Also a CD named "I was a Free Bird" which includes composed songs with lyrics of the writer was released by the museum. At the same time, Jabbarly Prize was created in connection with 100th jubilee of the writer and was presented to many artists.{{cite web|title= C.Cabbarlının ev-muzeyi|url= https://kataloq.gomap.az/az/all-poi/culture/museum/95be9566d56611e0ad4900226424597d|publisher= kataloq.gomap.az|language= az|accessdate=March 6, 2018}} ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:Biographical museums in Azerbaijan]] [[Category:Museums established in 1979]] [[Category:Architecture]]

<!--this article has used the BCE/CE convention since 11 May 2007--> {{Infobox building | name = House of the Faun | native_name = Casa del Fauno | native_name_lang = Italian | logo = | logo_size = | logo_alt = | logo_caption = | image = File:HouseOfTheFaunOverview.jpg
| image_size = | image_alt = <!-- or | alt = --> | image_caption = Front view of the house | map_type = | map_alt = | map_caption = | map_size = | map_dot_label = | map_dot_mark = | relief = | former_names = | alternate_names = | etymology = | status = | cancelled = | topped_out = | building_type = | architectural_style = | classification = | location = [[Pompeii]], [[Roman Empire]] | address = | location_city = <!-- or | location_town = --> | location_country = [[Italy]] | coordinates = | altitude = | current_tenants = | namesake = | groundbreaking_date = | start_date = 80 BC | stop_date = | est_completion = | topped_out_date = | completion_date = | opened_date = | inauguration_date = | relocated_date = | renovation_date = | closing_date = | demolition_date = <!-- or | destruction_date = --> | cost = | ren_cost = | client = | owner = | landlord = | affiliation = | height = | architectural = | tip = | antenna_spire = | roof = | top_floor = | observatory = | diameter = | circumference = | weight = | other_dimensions = | structural_system = | material = | size = | floor_count = | floor_area = | elevator_count = | grounds_area = | architect = | architecture_firm = | developer = | engineer = | structural_engineer = | services_engineer = | civil_engineer = | other_designers = | quantity_surveyor = | main_contractor = | awards = | designations = | known_for = | ren_architect = | ren_firm = | ren_engineer = | ren_str_engineer = | ren_serv_engineer = | ren_civ_engineer = | ren_oth_designers = | ren_qty_surveyor = | ren_contractor = | ren_awards = | rooms = <!-- or | unit_count = --> | parking = | website = <!-- {{URL|example.com}} --> | embed = | embedded = | references = | footnotes = }} [[File:HAVE - House in Pompeii.jpg|thumb|The "HAVE" Mosaic (spelling variant of [[Ave]])]] [[File:StatueFaunePompéi.JPG|thumb|Copy of the Dancing Faun]] The '''House of the Faun''' ({{lang-it|Casa del Fauno}}), built during the 2nd century BC, was one of the largest and most impressive [[Domus|private residences]] in [[Pompeii]], Italy, and housed many great pieces of art. It is one of the most luxurious aristocratic houses from the [[Roman republic]], and reflects this period better than most archaeological evidence found even in [[Rome]] itself.<ref name="Grant1988">{{cite book |title=Civilization of the ancient Mediterranean: Greece and Rome |last=Grant |first=Michael |authorlink= |author2=Kitzinger, Rachel |year=1988 |publisher=Scribner's |location=New York |isbn=0-684-17594-0 |pages= |url= }}</ref>
==History== The House of the Faun was built in the 2nd century BC during the [[Samnium|Samnite]] period (80 BC).<ref>''[[Cambridge Ancient History]].'' [New] ed. London: Cambridge University Press, 1970.</ref> There is evidence, most notably in the eastern walls of the [[tetrastyle]] [[Atrium (architecture)|atrium]], that after the [[62 Pompeii earthquake|great earthquake in AD 62]], the House of the Faun was rebuilt and/or repaired;<ref name="Dwyer2001">{{cite journal |last=Dwyer |first=Eugene J. |authorlink= |year=2001 |title=The Unified Plan of the House of the Faun |journal=Journal of the Society of Architectural Historians |volume=60 |issue=3 |pages=328–343 |doi=10.2307/991759 |jstor= 991759}}</ref> yet, the building was only used again until AD 79, ultimately rendered unusable by the [[Eruption of Mount Vesuvius in 79|eruption]] of [[Mount Vesuvius]]. Although the eruption was devastating, the layers of [[Volcanic ash|ash]] covering the city preserved artworks, like the [[mosaic]]s of the House of the Faun, which would have otherwise been likely destroyed or decayed due to the passage of time.
The House of the Faun was named for the bronze statue of the dancing [[faun]] located, originally, on the lip of the [[impluvium]], a basin for catching rainwater; it has been moved to the center of the impluvium, as seen in the adjacent picture. [[Faun]]s are spirits of untamed woodland, which literate and [[Hellenization|Hellenized]] Romans often connected to [[Pan (mythology)|Pan]] and Greek [[satyr]]s, or wild followers of the Greek god of wine and drama, [[Dionysus]]. It is purely decorative sculpture of a high order: "the pose is light and graceful," [[Sir Kenneth Clark]] observed,<ref>Clark, ''The Nude: A Study in Ideal Form'' 1956:263 (illustrated fig. 145).</ref> the modeling well understood, the general sense of movement admirably sustained," though he missed in its suavity the stimulus of sharper contrasts to be found in Renaissance nudes.
Archaeologists discovered an inscription bearing the [[cognomen]] Saturninus, suggesting that the dwelling was owned by the important [[gens]], or clan, Satria; a ring bearing the family name [[Cassius (gens)|Cassius]] was also found, indicating that someone of the Cassii family married into the ''gens'' Satria and lived in the House of the Faun.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Gordon |first=Mary L. |authorlink= |year=1927 |title=The Ordo of Pompeii |journal=Journal of Roman Studies |volume=17 |issue= |pages=165–183 |doi=10.2307/296132 |jstor= 296132}}</ref>
The House of the Faun was initially excavated in 1830 by the German archeological institute.
==Artworks== [[File:Alexandermosaic.jpg|thumb|left|The Alexander Mosaic]] The House of the Faun contained the [[Alexander Mosaic]], depicting the [[Battle of Issus (333 BC)|Battle of Issus]] in 333 BC between [[Alexander the Great]] and [[Darius III of Persia]]. This mosaic may be inspired by or copied from a Greek painting finished in the late fourth century BC,<ref name="Grant1988" /> probably by the artist [[Philoxenus of Eretria]].<ref>[[Pliny the Elder]], ''Natural History'' xxxv. 10.36§ 22.</ref> Unlike most Pompeian pavements of the late second and early first centuries, this mosaic is made of [[Tessellation|tesserae]], and not the more common [[opus signinum]], or other kinds of stone chips set in mortar.<ref name="Westgate2000">{{cite journal |last=Westgate |first=Ruth |authorlink= |year=2000 |title=''{{lang|la|Pavimenta Atque Emblemata Vermiculata}}'': Regional Styles in Hellenistic Mosaic and the First Mosaics At Pompeii |journal=American Journal of Archaeology |volume=104 |issue=2 |pages=255–275 |doi=10.2307/507451 |jstor= 507451}}</ref>
The Alexander Mosaic is complemented by other floor mosaics with [[Nilotic]] scenes and theatrical masks.<ref name="Grant1988" /> Other notable works of art from the House of Faun include an erotic ''Satyr and Nymph'' and the fish mosaic, a piece closely resembling other mosaics in Pompeii.<ref name="Westgate2000" />
==Architecture== [[File:House of the Faun.svg|alt=Building Plan of the House of the Faun|frame|256x256px|Building Plan]] The House of the Faun covers nearly 3000 square meters and occupies an entire city block, or ''[[Insulae|insula]]''. The house can be divided into five major parts: the Tuscan atrium, peristyle atrium, service rooms and corridors, first, or [[Ionic order|Ionic]], [[peristyle]], and second, or [[Doric order|Doric]], peristyle, and their corresponding dependent rooms.<ref name="Dwyer2001" /> Like many ancient Roman houses, the House of the Faun had ''[[taberna]]e'', or storefront shops, and a highly sophisticated building plan, which details the many rooms. The entrance is decorated by the [[Latin]] message “[[ave|HAVE]]”, a greeting both for meeting and parting.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/|title=Perseus Digital Library|publisher=}}</ref>
Like other wealthy aristocrats of the Roman Republic, the owners of the House of the Faun installed a [[Ancient Roman bathing|private bath system]], or ''[[balneum]]'', in the house. The bathing room was located in the domestic wing, which was to the right of the entrance, and along with the kitchen was heated by a large furnace.<ref name="Grant1988" /> The servants’ quarters were dark and cramped, and there was not much furniture.<ref>{{cite book |title=The Princeton Encyclopedia of Classical Sites |last=Stillwell |first=Richard |authorlink= |author2=MacDonald, William Lloyd |author3=McAllister, Marian Holland |year=1976 |publisher=Princeton University Press |location=Princeton, NJ |isbn= |pages= |url= }}</ref> The house features beautiful peristyle gardens, the second of which was created as a stage to host [[recitation]]s, [[Mime artist|mimes]], and [[pantomime]]s. Additionally, the house contained an entrance passage, a number of bedrooms (''cubicula''), dining rooms (''[[Triclinium|triclinia]]'') for both the summer and winter, a reception room (''[[oecus]]''), and an office (''[[tablinum]]'').<ref name="Grant1988" />
==Remains== [[File:HoFTourists.jpg|thumb|Tourists in the garden]] Today visitors can still explore the remains of the House of the Faun in modern Pompeii, along Via di Nola. Although most of the original artworks have been relocated to the [[Naples National Archaeological Museum|National Archaeological Museum]] (''Museo Archeologico Nazionale'') in [[Naples]], the most famous pieces, like the Dancing Faun and the Alexander Mosaic, have been recreated to give tourists a clearer picture of what the house was originally like.<ref name="Merola2006">{{cite journal |last=Merola |first=Marco |authorlink= |year=2006 |title=Alexander, Piece by Piece |journal=Archaeology |volume=59 |issue=1 |pages= |url=http://www.archaeology.org/0601/abstracts/mosaic.html |accessdate= }}</ref> Pietro Giovanni Guzzo, one of Pompeii’s past archaeological superintendents, explained, “I want visitors to have the impression that they are entering the same luxurious house in which the ancient Pompeian owners lived before it was destroyed by the eruption of Mount Vesuvius in AD 79.”<ref name="Merola2006" />
==See also== *[[House of Sallust]] *[[House of the Vettii]] *[[Roman gardens]]
==Gallery== <gallery> File:Nile Scene Mosaic.JPG|Mosaic with a [[Nile]] Scene Image:Satyrnymph.jpg|Erotic mosaic of a [[satyr]] and [[nymph]] Image:HoFOpus.jpg|[[Opus Sectile]] in vestibulum File:Theatre mask mosaic MAN Napoli Inv9994.jpg|Fruit and masks mosaic (detail) </gallery>

M. G. |authorlink= |year=1935 |title=The Decoration of The Hellenistic Peristyle House in South Italy |journal=American Journal of Archaeology |volume=39 |issue=3 |pages=360–371 |doi=10.2307/498623 |jstor= 498623}}

{{Infobox Artwork | image_file=Annibale Carracci - Hunting - WGA04417.jpg | title=Hunting Scene | artist=[[Annibale Carracci]] | year=before 1595 | medium=[[oil painting|Oil]] on canvas | height_metric=136 | width_metric=253 | metric_unit= cm | imperial_unit= in | city=[[Paris]] | museum=[[Louvre]] }}
'''''Hunting''''' (or ''Hunting Scene'') is a painting by Italian artist [[Annibale Carracci]], painted before 1595 and given to [[Louis XIV]] by Prince [[Camillo Pamphili]] in 1665. It is currently held and exhibited at the [[Louvre]] in [[Paris]].
==History== The painting and its companion, ''[[Fishing (Annibale Carracci)|Fishing]]'', were included in [[Charles Le Brun]]'s inventory in 1683, and in November 1695 they were in the apartments of [[King Louis XIV]]'s younger brother. It was no doubt for this purpose that they were given two sumptuous gilt frames, each with attributes suited to the subject of the painting – among the finest examples of the art of [[picture frame|frame-making]] in the time of Louis XIV. In 1955, when the varnish was being cleaned, the 19th century gilding covering the original gilding was removed – a task of some magnitude which was carried out by the French firm of Lebrun.<ref>H. Loyrette, ''The Louvre: All the Paintings'', Black Dog & Leventhal (2011), ''s.v. Carracci''.</ref>
This work, together with its companion, date from Carracci's [[Bologna|Bolognese]] period, before he left for [[Rome]] in 1595 to paint at the [[Palazzo Farnese|Galleria Farnese]]. At this time he was extremely interested in [[landscape]], and his experiments are a foreshadowing of [[Poussin]]'s classical compositions; but in these pictures he is exploring in a different direction, in the tradition of the [[Bassano (disambiguation)#Visual_arts|Bassani]], a family of painters whose studios continued to turn out landscapes which were prized all over [[Europe]]. His interest was the [[countryside]]. Without any religious theme as pretext, he painted two pure landscapes whose true subjects are the forest and the river, motivated by the themes of [[hunting]] and [[fishing]]. Therefore Carracci was able to show nature animated with the life of the [[aristocracy]] and of ordinary people. The composition follows the visual device of division into compartments.<ref>H. Loyrette, ''ibid.'', Ch.I, ''Italian School''.</ref>
[[Image:Annibale Carracci - Fishing - WGA4414.jpg|thumb|right|300px|''[[Fishing (Annibale Carracci)|Fishing Scene]]'' by [[Annibale Carracci]] (before 1595),1.36 m x 2.53m]]
Along with the Galleria Farnese, these two thematic paintings are among Carracci's masterpieces, and have always been much admired by artists. [[Manet]] found inspiration in the ''[[Fishing (Annibale Carracci)|Fishing]]'', and the ''Hunting'' has been copied by [[Matisse]], [[Edvard Munch]] and [[Rouault]].<ref>D. Benati & E. Riccomini, ''Annibale Carracci'', [[Mondadori]] Electa (2006), ''s.v. "Fishing Scene"''.</ref>
==Footnotes== <references/>

Fiesole 2000. * A. W. A. Boschloo: ''Annibale Carracci in Bologna: visible reality in art after the Council of Trent'', 's-Gravenhage 1974. * C. Goldstein: ''Visual fact over verbal fiction: a study of the Carracci and the criticism, theory, and practice of art in Renaissance and baroque Italy'', Cambridge 1988. * D. Posner: Annibale Carracci: a study in the reform of Italian painting around 1590, 2 vol., New York 1971. * S. Ginzburg: Annibale Carracci a Roma: gli affreschi di Palazzo Farnese, Roma 2000. * C.
